intro: Calamus latifolius, commonly known as broadleaf calamus, is a member of the Arecaceae family, native to tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It is a tall, slender plant that can grow up to 3 meters in height, characterized by its broad, flat leaves that are often used in traditional crafts. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in dense clusters, followed by elongated, spadix-like fruits. Its rhizomes are aromatic and have been traditionally used in perfumery and as a flavoring agent. Calamus latifolius thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in swampy or marshy areas.
